snippet: Residents of Kabul are lucky to have a few hours of electricity a day after lines carrying much of it were cut — most in areas contested or controlled by the Taliban.
abstract: Deadly attacks between Afghans and insurgents culminate in power shortages after lines that carry much of Kabul’s electricity are cut in Baghlan Province and Tajikistan, reducing capital’s power supply by about 80 percent; insurgents deny responsibility for cut lines while residents struggle to make do with limited supply of electricity.

byline.contributor: Jawad Sukhanyar and Ahmad Shakib contributed reporting from Kabul, and Najim Rahim from Kunduz, Afghanistan.

lead_paragraph: Residents of Kabul are lucky to have a few hours of electricity a day after lines carrying much of it were cut — most in areas contested or controlled by the Taliban.

headline.main: Afghanistan’s Crippled Power Grid Exposes Vulnerability of Besieged Capital
headline.print_headline: Crippled Power Grid Shows Afghans’ Vulnerability
